properties.about: Slow-moving water on the Green River (west side of Canyonlands National Park) with visitors from John Wesley Powell to uranium miners.

properties.point of interest: Confluence of Colorado and Little Colorado Rivers – inside of Grand Canyon NP. Often very cool glacial blue-white water from L. CO mixing with brown or dk green of CO river.

properties.about: Test

A 40-mile stretch of the Verde is designated as a ―Wild and Scenic River (one of only two such designations in Arizona). the Verde watershed is one of Arizona’s most important water-producing areas, supporting significant riparian habitat – including one of the last Fremont cottonwood/Goodding willow forests in Arizona. Habitat along the Verde and its tributaries supports: - Over 200 bird species, including the largest number of bald eagle nesting sites in Arizona; - One of the most diverse native fish populations in Arizona, including the endangered Razorback Sucker; - Populations of river otter (which to date are found in only three Arizona rivers) and beavers, which are returning to the Verde and restoring watershed health through dam-building activities; and - Large populations of elk, deer, bear, and mountain lions in the higher elevations of the watershed. Learn more
The San Pedro is one of the last undammed desert river in the American Southwest. In 1988, Congress created the San Pedro Riparian National Conservation Area. Learn more
Stunning granite peaks at the headwaters of the Green River.  Rock climbers’ paradise (have your been to Cirque of the Towers?) with returning grizzly bears.
This cowboy/ski town at the headwaters of the Yampa River is known for it's beauty, champagne powder and great summer tubing!

properties.photo credit: InSapphoWeTrust from Los Angeles, California, USA
properties.about: Dinosaur footprints, yes, but also one of the most spectacular white water canyons anywhere in the West!
Float through this slow-moving, calm water section of the Green River just West of Canyonlands National Park to be emerged in history and geology. Learn more
West of Canyonlands National Park lies this remote and beautiful desert canyon.
Along the San Juan River – lots of settlements in the past, from native peoples, Mormons, to more new-age folks today.

Very arid land draining north into the San Juan and south into the Little Colorado. Home to ancient pueblo cultures (ancestors of Hopi) and, for past 500 years, the Navajos who moved from the north. Lots of interesting grazing and mining issues and well as the Navajo Generating Station (huge coal plant) just outside Paige, AZ.
properties.point of interest: Navajo and Hopi lands (northeast corner of AZ)

properties.about: On U.S. national forest lands at the extreme headwaters of the Gila.  Home to hot springs and, recently, huge fires. Aldo Leopold Wilderness in NM is first in the country.
waters in lower reach are fed by Blue Springs complex, among largest in AZ (101,000 gpm); heavily mineralized water and travertine deposits. Headwaters Baldy Peak 10,000+ elevation in eastern AZ
Highly mineralized waters form travertine deposits. 5 falls in all the most well-known is Havasu Falls (photo). Very popular destination
properties.point of interest: Havasupai falls on Havasupai Indian Reservation.

properties.about: 600 foot cliffs, Emerald Cave, hot springs

zion National Park and Virgin River Gorge; The Virgin river flows uninterrupted from its headwaters above Zion NP (and spectacular sheer canyons) to Lake Mead. Segments of the River and some tributaries within Zion Park are part of the Federal Wild and Scenic River System (and I think the only designated system in Utah). The gorge, between St. George Utah and Littlefield, Arizona transitions from the Colorado Plateau to the Mojave Desert
is an incredible system with many spectacular side canyons and rich paleohistory, that now, unfortunately, flows into Lake Powell.
flows from Utah to the Colorado River at Lees Ferry, Arizona. It narrows to a slot canyon with sheer cliffs up to 1,000 feet high (incredible area)
; important migratory bird refuge, protects 30 river miles and one of the last remaining natural stretches of the lower Colorado River though the 20-mile long Topock Gorge. Contains Topock Marsh
at confluence with Lake Havasu protects one of the last stands of natural cottonwood-willow habitat along lower Colorado River and several endangered species
last unchannelized section of the river before it enters Mexico. Site of restoration efforts to maintain habitat for wintering migratory birds

Granite outcrops narrow the river and provided the only River crossing point for a thousand miles, making it a focal point for pre-historic and historic travel by tribal people, Spanish explorers, California gold seekers and immigrants

Upstream of Glenwood Spgs, CO. Has a full length bike path along the river, amazing scenery (including Hanging Lake), rafting, and was an engineering marvel when they built the highway in the ‘70s – had to bring over a special bridge building machine from Europe.

– the northern river entrance to Dinosaur National Monument on the Green River. Very imposing, kind of ominous looking “here we go into the bowels of the earth” kind of thing – excellent rafting (Stacy may have real pics)
– SW Colorado. Some of the closest together, sheer vertical walls in the US. WRA involvement in securing water rights for the park, big rock climbing destination.
properties.point of interest: Black Canyon of the Gunnison National Park
